src:
Pokukaj v prostor, kjer se je "rodil" internet

05 Nov 2019, 07:00


Poglejte priloženo fotografijo. 29. oktobra 1969 je študent - programer v točno tej sobi na UCLA poslal prvo sporočilo s sistemom ARPANET, predhodnikom interneta. A ni šlo vse po načrtih. Programer, Charley Kline, še ni mogel dobro izgovoriti besede "login", ko se je program sesul. Ja, začetek je bil bolj klavrn.

Po omenjenem dogodku je minilo še kar nekaj desetletij, preden je internet, kot ga poznamo danes, pričel vstopati v naše pisarne in domove. Naša življenja je preoblikoval do neslutenih razsežnosti, okoli njega pa se identificirajo celotne generacije.
Ob petdesetletnici prvega sporočila ARPANET-a obeležujejo pri Popular Mechanics spominski teden v raziskovanju svetlih in manj svetlih točk tega revolucionarnega globalnega komunikacijskega sistema. Ponovno bodo obiskali ali podoživeli znamenita spletna mesta, znana v preteklosti in sedanjosti, ki so ustvarila internet, takšen, kot ga poznamo danes. Prav tako bodo izpostavili družbene medije, ki so tako zelo razširjeni, in predstavili mesta v ZDA, kjer je internet še danes prepovedan.
50-obletnica je tudi priložnost, da se s poznavanjem preteklosti ozremo v prihodnost in kritično pogledamo na to, kaj nam bo internet lahko prinesel v prihodnosti oziroma kako bo vplival na naša življenja.
text:
Take a look at the place where the internet was born

05 Nov 2019, 07:00


Look at the attached photo. On October 29, 1969, a programmer in this particular room at UCLA sent the first message using ARPANET, the precursor to the Internet. But not everything went as planned. The programmer, Charley Kline, could not yet pronounce the word "login" well when the program crashed. Yes, the beginning was more clunky.

After the event, several decades passed before the Internet, as we know it today, began to enter our offices and homes. He has transformed our lives to unprecedented proportions, and entire generations are identified around him.
On the fiftieth anniversary of ARPANET's first announcement, Popular Mechanics is commemorating a week in exploring the bright and light spots of this revolutionary global communications system. They will revisit or relive the famous sites known in the past and present that have created the Internet as we know it today. They will also highlight the so-widespread social media and showcase places in the US where the internet is still banned.
The 50th Anniversary is also an opportunity to look to the past with a knowledge of the past and to take a critical look at what the Internet will bring us in the future or how it will affect our lives.
